That is not correct.

Remember NSGs are stateful, when the Ping request (technically ICMP Echo request) is passed through NSG, NSG registers it on its state table, then when Pong (ICMP Echo reply) shows up from VM2, NSG will find it matches the incoming Ping hence will allow it to go through.

If VM2 sends an ICMP Echo reply to VM1 without VM1 initiating it first, subnet-level NSG will simply block it since there is no matching entry on its state table.

Moreover, the correct answer will only allow VM1 to ping VM2, not the other way around. If we want VM2 to be able ping VM1, we will then need a reciprocal rule in place.
